Review Hollow and substrate-supported Prussian blue, its analogs, and their derivatives for green water splitting Jing-Yi Xie Bin Dong * College of Science, State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (East China), Qingdao 266580, Shandong, China College of Science State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum (East China) Qingdao Shandong 266580 China College of Science, State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (East China), Qingdao 266580, Shandong, China * Corresponding author. Tel/Fax: +86-532-86981156 Tel/Fax: +86-532-86981156 To meet the current energy needs of society, the highly efficient and continuous production of clean energy is required. One of the key issues facing the green hydrogen evolution is the construction of efficient, low-cost electrocatalysts. Prussian blue (PB), Prussian blue analogs (PBAs), and their derivatives have tunable metal centers and have attracted significant interest as novel photo- and electrochemical catalysts. In this review, recent research progress into PB/PBA-based hollow structures, substrate-supported nanostructures, and their derivatives for green water splitting is discussed and summarized. First, several remarkable examples of nanostructured PB/PBAs supported on substrates (copper foil, carbon cloth, and nickel foam) and hollow structures (such as single-shelled hollow boxes, open hollow cages, and intricate hollow structures (multi–shell and yolk–shell)) are discussed in detail, including their synthesis and formation mechanisms. Subsequently, the applications of PB/PBA derivatives ((hydr)oxides, phosphides, chalcogenides, and carbides) for water splitting are discussed. Finally, the limitations in this research area and the most urgent challenges are summarized. We hope that this review will stimulate more researchers to develop technologies based on these intricate PB/PBA structures and their derivatives for highly efficient, green water splitting. Graphical abstract In this review, we discuss PB/PBAs and their derivatives having advanced nanostructures such as hollow structures, as well as substrate-supported structures, and the applications of the derivatives ((hydr)oxides, phosphides, chalcogenides, and carbides) in green water splitting. Keywords Prussian blue Prussian blue analogues Hollow structure Substrate-supported structures Green water splitting 1 Introduction Global demand for power is increasing exponentially. At the same time, there is an urgent need to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels to reduce ever-increasing carbon emissions. Therefore, the discovery of new energy sources and energy carriers is urgently required [1–9]. Hydrogen is an ideal energy carrier because of its zero-carbon content and high gravimetric energy density compared to those of other fuels [10–18]. At present, there are three main strategies for industrial hydrogen production (Fig. 1(a) ): steam methane reforming (SMR), coal gasification (CG), and water electrolysis (WE). SMR and CG account for 95% of the world’s total hydrogen production, whereas WE accounts for only 4% [19,20]. Although SMR and CG have lower costs, WE can produce high-purity H2 without CO2, and this is consistent with environmental protection goals. Fig. 1(b) shows that traditional precious-metal-based materials are outstanding electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and can reduce the energy barrier to electrochemical processes and, thus, accelerate the electrochemical reaction rate [21–25]. However, the scarcity and high cost of precious metals has hindered the industrial application of these electrocatalysts [26–30]. Thus, to date, there has been significant research into finding alternatives for water electrolysis, especially the design and synthesis of efficient and low-cost electrocatalysts. In particular, transition-metal-based electrocatalysts possessing Pt/Ru-like electrochemical behavior (Fig. 1(b)) have attracted the attention of researchers, particularly cobalt-, nickel-, and iron-based materials [23,31–36]. Coordination polymers (CPs) have been widely used in adsorption, catalysis, and energy storage because of their metal contents, tunable internal compositions, high specific surface areas, and ordered structures. [37]. Discovered in the 18th century, Prussian blue (PB) (Fe4[Fe(CN)6]3⋅xH2O, where x = 14–16) was the first artificial CP. PB is synthesized by the solution coprecipitation of an FeIII salt and [FeII(CN)6]4− [38]. The PB framework has a face-centered cubic (fcc) unit cell (dimension: 10.2 Å), in which FeIII ions are surrounded by N atoms and FeII ions are surrounded by C atoms [39]. In this review, we discuss recent progress in the design of PB- and Prussian blue analog (PBA)-based electrocatalysts and their electrocatalytic and photocatalytic water splitting properties. First, PB/PBA frameworks are introduced concisely. Subsequently, the latest progress in the synthesis of PB- and PBA-based hollow structures, such as single-shelled hollow boxes, open hollow cages, and intricate hollow structures, as well as substrate-supported nanostructures, is discussed. In addition, we explain the hollowing mechanism. Next, we discuss how derivatives of PB/PBAs (i.e., (hydr)oxides, phosphides, chalcogenides, and carbides) can be used in water splitting. Finally, a summary of recent progress and challenges in this area is provided. 2 Designing PB and PBAs 2.1 Structures of PB and PBAs PB has captivated the interest of scientists for more than two centuries. PB can be readily prepared by the reaction between Fe3+ and an aqueous solution of ferrocyanide ions (Fe(CN)6 4−) [38,40]. The formation of this pigment can be expressed by the reaction 4Feaq 3+ +3Fe(CN)6 4− → Fe4[Fe(CN)6]3·xH2O (x = 14–16). The resulting material has a cubic framework (space group: Fm3–m, fcc unit cell parameter: 10.2 Å) with alternative divalent iron and trivalent iron sites at the cube corners linked by cyanide ligands (–C≡N–) [41]. In this structure, low-spin trivalent iron is bonded to carbon, whereas the high-spin divalent iron is bonded to nitrogen. Fig. 2(a) shows a defectless cubic PB cell. The charge imbalance caused by the 4:3 ratio of trivalent and divalent iron in PB can be counteracted by randomly distributed lattice defects in the form of ferricyanide cluster vacancies [42–44]. There are two types of PB structures: insoluble and soluble. As shown in Fig. 2(b), insoluble PB (empirical formula: Fe3[Fe(CN)6]2⋅xH2O, x = 14–16) is a complex of ferric-hexacyanoferrate(II), in which H2O molecules occupy the positions of the nitrogen ligands in vacant sites to complete the pseudo-octahedral coordination of Fe(II). In addition, the unit cell contains eight uncoordinated H2O molecules, which are hydrogen-bonded to the coordinated water molecules. Intriguingly, H2 may interact with the open coordination sites at the Fe(II) ions after the removal of the bound water molecules [45,46]. In contrast, soluble PB (Fig. 2(c), empirical formula: A4–y Fe y [Fe(CN)6]⋅zH2O, y = 0–1), which has the same coordinated H2O ligands as insoluble PB, contains alkali metal ions in the lattice cavities [47–49]. To improve the electrochemical response of PB, PBAs have been rationally designed via the partial or complete substitution of the metal component. PBAs have similar crystal structures to PB, as shown in Fig. 2, in which cyanide ligands act as bridges between different transition metals (M2+–C≡N–M3+). The empirical chemical formula for PBAs is A a MA[MB(CN)6] b ⋅xH2O (where A is the alkaline metal ion (e.g., Na+ or K+), MA and MB are transition metals (e.g., Co, Ni, Zn, or Mn), and a, b, and x are the corresponding stoichiometric values) [51–54]. Including other transition metal ions or replacing the metallic species can alter the electron distribution in the octahedral coordination environment of the PBA and may enhance stability and increase the specific surface area. 2.2 Advantages and disadvantages of PB and PBAs The advantages of the PB and PBA structures are as follows: (1) The metal centers are tunable. The Fe center of PB can be replaced by various metal ions with different valence states (e.g., Co, Ni, Zn, and Mn) and different coordination environments (e.g., Fe(CN)6 3−, Fe(CN)6 4−, and Co(CN)6 3−), resulting in electrochemically active analogs of Prussian blue (i.e., PBAs) [46,55,89]. (2) Secondary metallic species can be introduced into the PB and PBA systems, which allows the functionalization of PB via the introduction of further valence states. In addition, electron transfer between the metal centers is efficiently mediated by the cyanide ligands. (3) The large number of potential derivatives broadens the applications of PB/PBAs. The facile thermal treatment of PBAs can be used to prepare derivatives such as (hydr)oxides, phosphides, chalcogenides, and carbides [56–71]), and these materials have applications in catalysis, sensing [72,73], carbon-capture technologies, and energy production and storage [74–81]. (4) The morphologies are tunable. Starting from simple solid cubic particles, various PB/PBA morphologies (e.g., hollow microboxes, core-shell, multi-shell, nanocages, and substrate-supported nanostructures [82–84]) have been developed in the past decade. These well-designed frameworks promote electrolyte diffusion, increase the surface area, and have more exposed active sites for enhanced electrochemical performance. (5) The electron density is tunable. Because of the difference in electronegativity between metallic and nonmetallic atoms, the –C≡N– groups can mediate the electron density of the metal centers. (6) Because PB and PBAs contain carbon atoms, their derivatives after calcination exhibit excellent electrical conductivity. However, the physical structures of PB and PBAs are unstable and prone to collapse, especially after calcination at high temperatures. In addition, the sizes of PB and PBA particles are generally over 100 nm and cannot be scaled down, which prevents more active sites from being exposed. The advantages and disadvantages of PB/PBA are summarized in Table 1 . 3 Trends in PB and PBA synthesis To improve the structure of solid cubes of PB and PBAs and provide a large specific surface area to increase the exposure of a greater number, as well as more reactive, active sites, morphology design has attracted considerable attention. In recent decades, two prominent morphology design concepts have emerged for the development of PB and PBAs. One is to design hollow structures with large internal cavities and thin shells, such as single-shelled hollow boxes, open hollow cages, and intricate hollow structures (multi-shell and yolk-shell) [54,85–92]. The other is to deposit PB/PBAs on substrates such as copper foil (CF), carbon cloth (CC), and nickel foam (NF), although it is challenging to combine nanoscale materials built from two- or three-dimensional building blocks efficiently [93]. For further information, Ref. [94] systematically introduces other traditional approaches for the synthesis of PB/PBAs and their derivatives. 3.1 Synthesis of PB- and PBA-based hollow structures 3.1.1 Single-shelled hollow boxes Single-shelled boxes are a relatively simple framework and represent the most common type of hollow PB/PBA-based nanomaterials reported to date. Compared with solid cubes, single-shelled hollow structures have greater specific surface areas and more exposed active sites. Here, we summarize four strategies for fabricating single-shelled boxes: hard and soft templating, acid etching, and cation exchange methods. (I) Soft templates. Templating using soft templates has drawn significant attention in the past decade [98]. Soft templates are mainly based on the use of emulsion droplets [99], as illustrated in Fig. 3(a) (approach I). Oil-in-water (O/W) or water-in-oil (W/O) emulsions are most usually applied, and these are prepared by mixing immiscible solutions and using amphiphilic surfactants for stabilization. The groundbreaking use of a soft template to synthesize hollow PB spheres was reported by Wang et al. [39]. In their work, toluene was used as the oil phase to form an O/W emulsion of water and hexadecane. An organometallic surfactant based on a multipolymer terminated with pentacyanoferrate acted as the PB precursor and surfactant. Spherical PB shells were formed on the outside of these droplets on the addition of iron ions (Fig. 3(b)). This process has been denoted “miniemulsion periphery polymerization (MEPP)”. As shown in Fig. 3(c), the nanoparticles had hollow ring-like morphologies. (II) Hard templates. Compared to the soft templating method, that using hard templates provides the possibility of forming spherical, nonspherical, and more complicated hollow structures. [100,101]. The hard templating method, which can be used to prepare different hollow micro-/nanostructures, is the most effective and common method (Fig. 3(a), approach II). For example, the Risset group reported a hard template scheme to synthesize hollow RbMFe (M = Co, Ni) PBA nanoboxes [95]. Notably, the RbMFe shell grew on the RbMnFe template by direct deposition. Then, the particles were washed under very mild conditions, which prevented the empty shells from collapsing. This hard templating method resulted in the increased solubility of the RbMnFe PBA compared to those of other PBA materials. As a result, well-designed box nanoparticles having a shell of approximately 23 nm were constructed (Figs. 3(d) and 3(e)). However, the use of hard templates has some disadvantages. For example, large-scale production is challenging because of the multistep synthetic method. In addition, the shells lack mechanical strength without a template. Furthermore, it is challenging to refill the interior with functional species. (III) Etching. Chemical etching with HCl is another common method for the preparation of hollow PB structures [96,102] (Fig. 3(a), approach II). For instance, Yamauchi et al. [103–105] introduced a simple method to synthesize uniform hollow PB cubes via acid etching. In their work, solid PB cubes were converted into hollow boxes after treatment with HCl followed by low-temperature calcination (Figs. 3(f) and 3(g)). Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) layers were found to be a key factor in the formation of the uniform hollow structures because they protected the shells from excessively fast etching. Hu et al. used PB as a precursor to prepare hollow boxes by alkaline etching. Specifically, Na2WO4·2H2O was used to etch solid PB cubes and form a thin layer of insoluble Fe(OH)3/WO3-x·yH2O, thus yielding hollow nanocages. Fig. 4(a) illustrates the ion-exchange process. Figs. 4(b) and 4(c) show the TEM and SEM images of the Fe-W PBA cubes, respectively. As shown in Figs. 4(d)–(f), W and Fe were evenly distributed over the surface of the cages. Crucially, because the etching rate at corners is faster than that at faces, the holes are etched from the corner to the edges and, finally, to the faces, which produces more active surface area and further defects [107–110]. (IV) Cation exchange. This is another efficient protocol for synthesizing hollow inorganic frameworks [99] (Fig. 3(a), approach IV). This approach is possible because of the differences in solubility of various PBAs. For example, compared to most PBAs, Mn-Fe PBA is unstable in solution because of its high solubility product (K sp = 1.9 × 10−3) [111]. Therefore, Mn-Fe PBA acts as a self-sacrificing template in the formation of hollow PB/PBA frameworks. In 2017, Wang et al. [97] synthesized hollow PBA nanoboxes using the cation exchange method. In the initial stages, Mn-Fe PBA was slowly disassociated in aqueous solution. As a result of the K sp, solid-liquid equilibrium (SLE) was reached during the dissolution of Mn-Fe PBA (Fig. 3(h)). Then, on adding cobalt ions, the [Fe(CN)6]2− units reacted with Co2+ to form a Co-Fe PBA layer on the surface of the Mn-Fe PBA. Crucially, Co-Fe PBA has a lower K sp (6.7 × 10−22) than the Mn-Fe PBA [112]. As shown in Fig. 3(i), the core-shell Mn-Fe/Co-Fe PBA was formed rapidly, and, eventually, hollow Co-Fe PBA microboxes were produced after the long-term consumption of ferricyanide ions, as illustrated in Fig. 3(j). 3.1.2 Open hollow cages Open hollow cages are another advanced PB/PBA structure. These structures are all based on hollow boxes, but the positions of the openings and the degrees of openness vary. The face centers and corners in these frameworks are the most common positions for openings after ion exchange or chemical etching. Yu et al. [87] demonstrated an approach to induce isotropic anion exchange/etching in Ni-Co PBA solid cubes to yield NiS nanocages with holes in each face center. Fig. 5(a) shows the morphology of the NiS nanocages prepared from the Ni-Co PBA nanocubes. In this process, the edges are preferentially etched by exchange with S2− because the rough surfaces expose more reactive defects for anion exchange than the smoother surfaces (Figs. 5(b)–(d)). In 2017, Nai et al. [113] successfully reported a strategy to assemble anisotropic KCoFe nanoparticles (NPs) into open frame-like superstructures via oriented attachment (OA). The morphology of the KCoFe nanoframes is shown in field-emission SEM (FESEM) images (Fig. 5(e)), in which the surfaces of each edge are smooth and approximately 115 nm thick. In Fig. 5(f), a single particle of the KCoFe nanoframes is shown, and its single crystal nature is shown by the selected area electron diffraction pattern in Fig. 5(g). Furthermore, Fig. 5(h) clearly shows lattice fringes, suggesting the high crystallinity of the nanoframe. In addition, the interplanar spacing is 5.0 Å, which corresponds to the (200) planes of KCoFe (Fig. 5(g)). Han et al. [114] introduced a novel Ni-Co PBA nanocage structure consisting of pyramid-like walls that were prepared at room temperature using a mild etching method. Specifically, they used an ammonia etching process that can be controlled by varying the aging time. The etching process, illustrated in Fig. 5(i), begins at the corners of the Ni-Co PBA nanocubes, and the final results are shown in the FESEM (Fig. 5(j)) and TEM (Figs. 5(k) and 5(l)) images of the Ni-Co PBA cages. After annealing the Ni-Co PBA cages in air at 350 °C, Ni-Co mixed oxide cages were obtained. After annealing, the cage morphology of the Ni-Co PBA particles was well-retained, but the particles had rougher surfaces (Figs. 5(m)–(o)). Similar work was carried out by Feng et al. [88]. As shown in Fig. 5(p), Co3O4 nanocages were fabricated by the calcination of Co-PBA nanocages that had been etched by ammonia. Interestingly, the Co-PBA and oxide derivative particles (Figs. 5(q)–(v)) have larger open holes at each corner and smoother surfaces than the Ni-Co PBA and oxide derivative particles prepared by Han et al. [114] (Figs. 5(j)–(o)). 3.1.3 Intricate hollow structures Intricate hollow structures have complex boundaries, interior cavities, and subunits. The advantage of these structures compared to hollow frameworks with a single shell is that they provide increased possibilities for regulating the corresponding physicochemical properties [54,115–119], which can result in new functionality and enhanced performance. Multi-shell coreshell structures are typical examples of intricate, hollow PB- and PBA-based structures synthesized to date [85,90–92]. Zhang et al. [91] demonstrated a method to control PB and other alkaline materials with template-based reactions. Their method allowed the large-scale preparation of complicated hollow structures under mild conditions. Here, we discuss the formation of hollow microboxes having single and multiple shells and hierarchical architectures (Fig. 6(a) , approach A). Ref. [91] is worthy of reference for readers interested in the preparation of complex hollow boxes that contain various elements and oxides/hydroxides of Fe (Fig. 6(a), approach B). Using approach A, the reaction between PB microcubes with different concentrations of aqueous NaOH and at different reaction temperatures led to the generation of shape-controlled Fe(OH)3 microboxes having multiple shells. The PB solid cubes were transformed into boxes with a large interior hole after reaction with 0.02 M NaOH solution at room temperature (Fig. 6(b)), whereas, on increasing the NaOH concentration to 0.2 M, porous cores were produced in the core-shelled box (Fig. 6(c)). In addition, after increasing the temperature to 80 °C, a box with a single shell was synthesized (Fig. 6(d)). In contrast, on increasing the concentration of the NaOH solution to 2.0–4.0 M at the same temperature, multi-shell boxes were formed (Figs. 6(e)–(g)). From these experimental observations, the authors determined that high temperatures and NaOH facilitate the diffusion of hydroxyl ions and the precipitation of Fe(OH)3, respectively. Thus, after the initial formation of the exterior Fe(OH)3 shell, a further inner shell of Fe(OH)3 is generated before the iron species transfer outside for precipitation on the outer shell. Through the above process, multi-shell structures are eventually obtained. Yolk-shell microboxes have also attracted considerable attention from researchers. In 2019, Hu et al. [92] synthesized a yolk-shell framework that was prepared via the HCl etching of PB mesocrystals. As shown in the SEM image of yolk-shelled Prussian blue (Fig. 6(h)), numerous crystals are clearly visible on the surface after the etching treatment. The TEM image of the yolk-shell Prussian blue in Fig. 6(i) shows the generation of the core-shell framework. In a typical reaction, PB cubes are etched by protons, which permeate the system via pores in the crystals, and the interior of the cubes is dissolved, thus forming a cavity. In contrast, the surface remains stable as a result of the use of PVP. Ye et al. [90] also synthesized a yolk-shell PB in 2019, although this structure contained self-assembled thin nanoplates on the outer shell. As shown in Fig. 6(j), the TEM images reveal that each microbox consists of a core and a shell, and a visible void can be seen. The nanoplates can be clearly seen in the SEM image (Fig. 6(k)). 3.2 Synthesis of PBAs on substrates Most PBAs and their derivatives are powders, making adsorption on conductive substrates challenging without the use of a polymer binder. The binder reduces conductivity, the number of active surface sites, and structural durability [120]. In addition, under high-temperature pyrolysis conditions, PBAs are prone to aggregation, resulting in unsatisfactory catalytic performance [121]. In 2018, Zhang et al. [21] presented a novel way to synthesize PBAs that grow on various substrates to overcome these barriers and enable the use of these hierarchical frameworks for wide applications. In their work, they demonstrated a mild, high-efficiency interfacial construction method based on ion exchange as the key process. This synthetic scheme enables the fabrication of a multidimensional framework by depositing three-dimensional PB/PBA onto two- and three-dimensional metal (hydr)oxides. In a typical synthetic process, the Co(OH)2 generated on the NF forms a 3D network structure of interwoven nanosheets. As the reaction time increases, the nanosheets become thicker, forming closely arranged cubes (Figs. 7(a)–(d) ). The pH of the reaction solution is an important factor in the growth process, and it was found that the pH changes with time (Fig. 7(e)). During the reaction, cobalt hydroxide dissolves to release Co2+ into the K3Fe(CN)6 solution, which is weakly acidic. Subsequently, Co2+ combines with Fe(CN)6 3− and precipitates because of the low K sp of Co-Fe PBA (1.8 × 10−15); thus, the pH falls [123]. This approach can be applied to numerous substrates such as CC and NF. In 2019, the same group made further improvements to their method that enabled control over the morphology and growth rates. This was achieved by adjusting the pH of the solution during reaction [122]. In general, the morphologies of PB and PBA can be tuned by adding surfactants (e.g., PVP) [124–127]. Interestingly, the addition of HCl to yield acidic conditions accelerates the release of metal ions by etching the metal substrates, thus providing another route to regulate the PBA structure. For example, Zhang et al. [122] grew nanocubes uniformly on a copper surface using an in situ redox reaction and precipitation deposition method (Fig. 7(f)). The effect of the reaction solution pH on the morphology was investigated by adding acid without surfactants, and well-aligned and rough hollow spheres were produced on the surface of the copper (Figs. 7(g) and 7(h)). Interestingly, this strategy has been frequently adopted to synthesize various PBAs on different metal substrates, such as Fe, Sn, and Zn plates, as well as NF (Figs. 7(i)–(p)), indicating that the morphologies of the PBAs are significantly affected by the metal substrate because of the different activities of metal ions and deposition rates of the PBAs. In addition to metal substrates that provide metal ions for the in situ fabrication of PBAs, seed-free substrates have been used, and the direct growth of PBAs on these substrates has drawn significant attention. In 2019, Chu et al. [128] presented a novel approach to synthesize well-ordered PB via a simple hydrothermal method using potassium ferricyanide, trisodium citrate dihydrate, and hydrochloric acid. Overall, these substrate-supported nanomaterials for PB and PBAs have significant potential. Having discussed the two main design trends for PB and PBAs, we now summarize their advantages and disadvantages (Fig. 8 ). Advantages of hollow structures: (1) There are various mature methods for the synthesis of different hollow structures. Starting from simple solid cubes of PB/PBAs, different morphologies, such as hollow microboxes, core-shell, multi-shell, and nanocages, can be prepared using the advanced modification methods developed in the past decade. The corresponding synthetic methods have also matured, for example, the use of soft and hard templates, chemical etching, and cation exchange. (2) Hollow structures with relatively large specific surface areas are promising because they expose many highly active sites. (3) Nanoscale powder catalysts allow better contact with electrolytes, which may improve electrocatalyst activity. Disadvantages of hollow structures: (1) The powdered material requires a polymer binder. Most PBAs and their derivatives are powdered materials that cannot be fixed to the surface of conductive substrates without the help of a polymer binder, leading to reduced conductivity, fewer active surface sites, and poor structural stability [120]. (2) During high-temperature pyrolysis, PBAs are prone to aggregation, resulting in unsatisfactory catalytic performance [121]. (3) The powder coating on the electrodes is easily washed away by the bubbles generated on the electrode at high current density. This is a potential problem for industrial hydrogen production via powder electrocatalysis. Advantages of substrate-supported structures: (1) Most substrate-supported structures are grown in situ. This prevents the catalyst from being washed away by the large bubbles created on the electrode. (2) Substrates with strong mechanical properties are conducive to industrial hydrogen production. Among these substrates, iron foam is a promising choice because of its strong mechanical properties [129,130]. Disadvantages of substrate-supported structures: Analysis of the chemical composition of the catalyst grown in situ on the substrate is challenging because of interference with the substrate itself. 4 Applications of PB/PBA-derived nanomaterials for catalytic water splitting 4.1 Applications of PB/PBA derived nanomaterials for electrocatalytic water splitting The production of H2 and O2 by solar-driven electrochemical water splitting is one of the most promising technologies in the field of solar power conversion and storage [131–133]. As alternatives to precious metal catalysts (e.g., Pt, RuO2, Ir, and Pd) [134–140], transition metal (TM) catalysts have attracted the interest of researchers [141–145]. PB/PBAs are rich in metal centers, which makes them candidates for catalysis. However, pristine PB and PBAs exhibit poor electrochemical stability in some electrolytes because they dissolve under strongly acidic or alkaline liquid conditions [146]. In contrast, derivative compounds prepared from PB/PBA precursors by methods such as annealing and phosphating can show enhanced intrinsic performance [147–149]. In this section, PB and PBA derivatives ((hydr)oxides, phosphides, chalcogenides, and carbides) and their use for electrocatalytic water splitting are discussed. 4.1.1 Metal (hydr)oxides Metal (hydr)oxides of earth-rich transition metals (such as Fe, Co, and Ni) are promising alternatives to traditional noble metal electrocatalysts for the OER [150]. They can be transformed into oxyhydroxides during the OER, which are the OER active sites. Current research into metal oxides derived from PB/PBAs is focused on the following four areas: (1) identifying the optimal calcination conditions for the metal oxides, (2) modifying the metal centers to enhance the intrinsic chemical performance, (3) tuning the morphologies of PB/PBAs to construct porous metal oxides, and (4) combining conductive substrates with PB/PBAs to enhance the conductivity. Thermal annealing in air is a common approach for synthesizing porous nanometal oxides [152,153]. In 2018, Wang et al. [151] systematically investigated the impact of the annealing temperature on the electrocatalytic activity using a NiFeII-PBA confined by KCl as an example. The PBA was calcined at different temperatures ranging from 300 to 800 °C. As shown in Fig. 9(a) , a NF was used as a sacrificial template, generating Ni2+ to enable the formation of Ni-FeII PBA. The catalyst obtained by the calcination of the PBA required an applied potential of 285 mV to reach a current density of 50 mA cm−2 (Fig. 9(b)). In addition, the corresponding chronoamperometry stability study revealed good durability, and the current density only decayed by 10% after 12 h of continuous testing. KCl encapsulation significantly promoted the exposure of active sites, electron transport, and catalyst stability. In addition to their effect on electrocatalytic activity, the calcination temperature and morphology also affect the chemistry of the resulting products. Hu et al. [152] obtained different types of crystalline Fe2O3 by tuning the thermal annealing temperatures and selecting PBs having different inner cavities. As shown schematically in Fig. 9(c), well-crystallized γ-Fe2O3 or α-Fe2O3 without impurity phases were rapidly obtained by the oxidation and crystallization of PB with large hollow cavities at 250 or 400 °C. In contrast, PB with no cavities or only small inner cavities underwent slow oxidation and crystallization because of the hindered diffusion of air. Thus, the majority of the Fe2O3 was not crystallized at low temperatures. However, as the temperature increased, crystalline iron oxide could also be obtained. Metal oxides supported on highly conductive substrates have also attracted the attention of researchers. For example, well-aligned mesoporous CoFe2O4 thin films have been obtained by annealing CoFe-PBA grown on Ni foam [154]. A composite having preferred [100] orientation was synthesized through a liquid-phase epitaxial approach with no structure-directing surfactants. Because of the efficient conductivity and dispersibility of the substrate, this OER electrocatalyst only required an applied potential of 290 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Further, density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed the reaction step involving the formation of O* has the highest Gibbs free energy and is, thus, rate-limiting: 2.68 and 3.08 eV for Co and Fe sites, respectively. These results also revealed that OH* is the main surface-adsorbed species, whereas Co is the main active site. Similarly, a variety of metal (hydr)oxides with different metal centers (Co, Ni, Fe, Cu, and Mn) and morphologies (nanowires, nanoparticles, and nanosheets) have been reported as OER electrocatalysts [21]. In these PBA-derived hydroxides, the metal center, structure, and the crystal properties can be tuned simultaneously (Figs. 9(d)–9(i)). In that work, an optimized PBA@Co(OH)2/NF catalyst was prepared, and it only required an applied potential 290 mV to achieve a current density of 20 mA cm−2 for the alkaline OER. In addition, spinel oxides can also be derived from PB and PBAs for catalytic applications. Wang and coworkers reported a novel and high-production strategy to regulate the composition of a ternary metallic PBA (M y Fe1–y Co, M = Mn, Co, Zn) based on the concept of “copolymer-comorphology” [155]. That is, if different morphologies can be obtained when using the same approach with a range of metal salts, the relative concentration can tune the final morphology. Taking Mn y Fe1–y Co as an example, a higher Mn concentration tends to result in a cube-shaped morphology, whereas a spherical morphology is obtained when using a higher Fe concentration (Figs. 10(a) and 10(b)). Moreover, the ratio of MnIII/MnIV octahedral sites was found to affect the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and OER activities (Fig. 10(c)). Furthermore, Guo et al. [156] used low-temperature air plasma to prepare reactive oxygen species at Co sites (Fig. 10(d)). The formation of 100% Co3+ sites was induced by the formation of CN− vacancies, which only form at Co centers. The final catalyst required an applied potential of 330 mV to achieve a current density of 100 mA cm−2 for the OER (Fig. 10(e)). 4.1.2 Metal phosphides Transition metal phosphides (TMPs), which have the formula M x P y , exhibit excellent hydrogen evolution performance. Electron delocalization in these state-of-the-art catalysts is limited by P because of its low electronegativity; therefore, electrons migrate from the metal to phosphorus atoms [157]. During the OER, phosphides are also prone to reconstruction to form (hydr)oxides, which act as the real electrocatalysts [158]. TMPs derived from PB/PBAs are generally prepared by gas-phase phosphating in a quartz tube with NaH2PO2, which serves as a P source, placed upstream. Recent studies on the preparation of series of catalysts have mainly focused on two methods: (1) the construction of a complex framework to yield porous TMPs, thus exposing more active sites, and (2) the anchoring of TMPs on porous and conductive substrates. Several different TMP catalysts prepared from PBAs having nanocube structures have been widely reported [162–165]. However, TMPs synthesized from PB and PBAs with complex frameworks have attracted the attention of researchers because of their excellent electrochemical performance. In particular, among the various TMPs, FeP is considered a potential catalyst for electrochemical water splitting. For example, Peng et al. [159] prepared a hollow carbon nanobox encapsulating monodispersed FeP nanoparticles (denoted FeP/HCNB). The synthesis of FeP/HCNB is illustrated in Fig. 11(a) . As shown, the formation of a hollow core results from the evaporation of zinc species, whereas the porous carbon shell is formed by the decomposition of polydopamine, resulting in a unique framework structure (Fig. 11(b)). The resulting FeP/HCNB yielded a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at voltages of –105 and –203 mV vs. the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) for H2 generation in both acidic and alkaline media, respectively, which are superior to those of Pt/C under the same conditions. In addition, the excellent electrochemical stability of FeP/HCNB was demonstrated by its ability to be used continuously for 15 h with a current retention of approximately 70%–80%. Our group has also explored complex FeP structures derived from PBAs using a reduction-cation exchange (RCE) strategy followed by phosphating (Fig. 11(c)) [160]. In this method, core-shell Fe-CoP nanocages are constructed from a CoFe PBA precursor. During the formation process, Fe2+ replaces Co2+ in Co3[Fe(CN)6]2 because of the different K sp values of Fe3[Fe(CN)6]2 and Co3[Fe(CN)6]2, resulting in the formation of holes in the centers of the faces. This open-cage core-shell structure increases the exposure of active sites and the specific surface area. Furthermore, efficient electron transport between Fe and Co is induced via O or P bridges after doping with Fe. Crucially, the electrocatalytic performance of the catalyst is enhanced by the optimized electronic structure. In fact, the resulting catalyst exhibited a Tafel slope of 35.2 mV dec−1 and yielded a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at 300 mV (vs. RHE) for O2 generation in alkaline media, which is better than that of RuO2. As mentioned, recent studies have focused on the preparation of porous TMPs or TMPs anchored on porous substrates. Cao et al. reported a Co-Fe PBA grown on a three-dimensional porous NF that showed excellent electrocatalytic activity after further phosphating [161]. As shown schematically in Fig. 11(d), a piece of cleaned NF was soaked for 1 d in a stirred solution of cobalt chloride, sodium citrate, and potassium ferricyanide. The Co-Fe PBA cubes were grown in situ on the NF via coprecipitation. NaH2PO2, which is the phosphorus source, combined with cobalt to form CoP after heating at 400 °C for 3 h, and the resulting self-supported Fe-doped CoP catalyst exhibited outstanding performance: current densities of 500 mA cm−2 (295 mV) and 1000 mA cm−2 (428 mV) at low overpotentials during the OER in alkaline solution (Fig. 11(e)). Meanwhile, controlled-current electrolysis (CCE) was maintained for 30 h without any obvious change at different current densities, thus demonstrating excellent stability. In addition, this catalyst shows excellent alkaline HER performance at 78 mV, yielding a current density of –10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 11(f)). The excellent electrocatalytic performance is a synergistic effect arising from the presence of mesopores and macropores, which yield abundant active sites, increase contact with the electrolyte, and facilitate the release of gases from the catalysts. The formation of nanopores in TMPs has drawn particular attention as a means to increase the accessible surface area for the electrolysis of water. Yu et al. [166] reported a template-based technique to prepare porous NiP derived from 2D Ni PBA nanoplates. As shown in Fig. 12(a) , the Ni-PBAs were treated with NaOH to obtain Ni(OH)2, followed by their calcination and low-temperature phosphating to yield NiP nanoplates. Benefiting from the unique nanostructure, as well as the OER-active oxidized nickel species grown in situ, the NiP nanoplates showed excellent O2 generation activity, delivering a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at 1.53 V (vs. RHE) in alkaline solution (Figs. 12(b) and 12(c)). This method was further used to synthesize hollow Ni5P4/Fe3P cubes having a larger electrode/electrolyte interface (Fig. 12(d)) [167]. Zhang et al. [167] coated the surface of the NiFe PBA with SiO2 to protect the structure from collapsing during phosphating, and it was subsequently etched by hydrofluoric acid to obtain a hollow structure (Fig. 12(e)). The final catalyst generated O2 at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at an applied voltage of 252 mV in alkaline media (Fig. 12(f)). 4.1.3 Metal chalcogenides Transition metal chalcogenides are promising electrocatalysts for the OER and HER owing to their high electrical conductivity and outstanding corrosion resistance [168–170], and a number of studies of these compounds, such as TC, TC2, T9S8, Ni3C2, and T3S4 (T = Fe/Co/Ni, C = S/Se/Te), have been reported [171–178]. Most of these compounds can be prepared by the thermal sulfidization or selenization of group VIII 3d metals using solid sulfur or selenium powder, but they can also be prepared by solvothermal methods using S-containing compounds (Na2S or MoS4 2−) in various solvents. During the OER, most metal chalcogenides can be easily electrochemically tuned in situ to form new catalyst surfaces, as previously mentioned [179,180]. Similar to research on PB/PBA-derived metal phosphides discussed in the previous section, current studies of metal chalcogenides derived from PB/PBAs focus on two directions: (1) constructing a complex framework to yield porous transition metal chalcogenides, thus exposing more active sites, and (2) the anchoring of transition metal chalcogenides on porous and conductive substrates. For example, a core (Co3S4)–shell (MoS2) heterostructure, which can evolve into an excellent bifunctional catalyst, was designed by Guo et al. (Figs. 13(a) and 13(b)) [181]. This unique structure was obtained in two steps: ion exchange between Fe(CN)63− (Co-Fe PBA) and S2– (Na2S) at 120 °C using a hydrothermal approach to construct a hollow Co3S4 framework. Subsequently, the MoS2 nanosheets grew in situ on the surfaces of the hollow Co3S4 precursor after high-temperature (200 °C) heating. The target catalyst exhibited a low overpotential for the OER (280 mV, Fig. 13(c)) and HER (136 mV, Fig. 13(d)) and achieved a current density of 10 mA·cm−2 in a 1.0 M KOH solution. Compared with that of RuO2, its current density decay over 10 h was negligible. Additionally, continuous cyclic voltammetry analysis for 2000 cycles from 1.0 to 1.6 V (vs. RHE) also revealed its durability. A model of the Co9S8/MoS2 interface was built by Ramos et al. [182] for DFT calculations, which revealed the creation of open latent vacancy sites on Mo atoms interacting with Co and the formation of Co–Mo bonds. Thereafter, a strong electron donation from Co to Mo occurs via the intermediate sulfur atom bonding to both metals, which can decrease the charge-migration resistance of the Co9S8/MoS2 heterostructure. This reaction mechanism can also be applied to the Co3S4@MoS2 system. However, these PBA-derived hollow sulfides and selenides still suffer from architecture collapse or aggregation because of the significant generation of gas. To enhance the conductivity and structural stability of individual particles, some researchers have attempted to anchor metal sulfides and selenides on porous and conductive substrates. For instance, Xu et al. [183] designed a penroseite (Ni,Co)Se2 nanocage immobilized on a three-dimensional graphene aerogel, which was obtained by the in situ growth of a PBA precursor on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) nanosheets and subsequent hydrothermal selenization (Fig. 13(e)). The strong coupling between the substrate and target catalyst promotes charge transfer and facilitates overall water electrolysis. As shown in Fig. 13(f), the produced electrode (so-called (Ni,Co)Se2-GA) achieved a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with a low overpotential of 250 mV for the OER in 1.0 M KOH, significantly better performance than that of RuO2. Further, the (Ni,Co)Se2-GA electrode requires only 128 mV to achieve a current density of –10 mA cm−2 for the HER in 1.0 M KOH solution, which is much higher than that of Pt/C (Fig. 13(g)). According to DFT calculations, the tendency of electrons to transfer from carbon (N-doped) to Co9S8 nanoparticles increases as the graphitic N to pyrrolic N doping ratio in the carbon increases. In addition, charge injection can decrease the reaction energy required for *OOH formation and, thus, facilitates O2 production on the Co9S8 (100) surface. Furthermore, a strongly repulsive charge distribution in the Co–O bond is also caused by electron injection, indicating bond weakening. All these results suggest that applying appropriate electronic interactions between Co9S8 and cobalt oxide/cobalt hydroxide promotes the OER. Chen et al. [170] utilized a simple technique to prepare Co9S8 nanoparticles encapsulated in a carbon matrix prepared from a PBA precursor through a simultaneous sulfidation and carbonization process followed by annealing at different controlled temperatures (Fig. 13(h)). In this process, on increasing the heat-treatment temperature, the coordinated cyanide ligands in the PBAs generate N-doped graphitic carbon (N-GC), N-doped carbon nanotubes (N-CNTs), or N-doped amorphous carbon (N-AC). Thus, the strength of the interaction between Co9S8 and the carbon matrix can be controlled by adjusting the annealing temperature. The results of OER electrochemical analyses and DFT calculations suggest that the combination of graphitic and pyrrolic N promotes the electron migration capability of Co9S8 and tunes the adsorption free energy of O2, thereby greatly improving the OER catalytic efficiency. The Co9S8 encapsulated in N-CNTs exhibited a relatively low overpotential (302 mV) to deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2 for the OER in 1.0 M KOH solution, as detailed in Fig. 13(i). Nai et al. [184] reported a self-template technique to synthesize Ti-Fe mixed sulfide nanoboxes for the OER. As shown in Fig. 14(a) , the Ti-Fe PBA nanocubes were solvothermally treated in dimethyl formamide (DMF) and subsequently vulcanized with hydrogen sulfide decomposed from thiourea under a nitrogen atmosphere (Fig. 14(b)). Consequently, the Ti-Fe mixed sulfide nanoboxes achieved a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a small overpotential (350 mV) in a 1.0 M KOH solution (Fig. 14(c)). Impressively, current densities of 5 and 10 mA cm−2 could be maintained for 12 h, showing attenuation of only approximately 0.5% and 1.0%, respectively, thus confirming the good durability of the catalyst (Fig. 14(d)). 4.1.4 Metal carbides Metal carbides show excellent electrocatalytic performance owing to their high conductivities and stabilities [185–189]. In addition, the combination of carbides and metals enables the synergistic enhancement in catalytic ability. As described in the previous section, PB and PBAs have a cubic framework, a uniform elemental distribution, and abundant cyanide ligands (–C≡N–), which can act as a carbon source for carbide formation. The uniformly dispersed metal centers can combine with the carbon on thermal treatment, yielding metal carbides. Furthermore, ex situ post-OER characterization and in situ Raman spectra have verified that the metal carbide surfaces are transformed into active species ((hydr)oxides) for water oxidation [190]. To enhance the stability of FeP, Zhu et al. [191] designed a carbon protective coat for hollow mesoporous FeP microcubes. The coating was added using a facile solution strategy, followed by annealing and phosphatizing treatment (Fig. 15(a) ). The high-resolution TEM image (Fig. 15(b)) of the hollow mesoporous FeP@C microcube shows lattice fringes corresponding to the (011) and (111) crystal planes of FeP and a curved amorphous carbon structure, suggesting that the carbon-coated nanocomposite had been successfully formed. The carbon layer effectively decreased the contact resistance between each microstructure and accelerated electron transport, leading to excellent HER activity. As shown in Fig. 15(c), the target catalyst (HMFeP@C) required an overpotential of 115 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and exhibited excellent H2 generation activity and durability in acidic solution. Carbon is a highly conductive medium, so many researchers have used it as a substrate to enhance the electron migration efficiency between the electrolyte and metals. For example, Zhao et al. [192] encapsulated a series of Co nanoparticles in a reduced graphene oxide catalyst codoped with Co and N (Co@Co-N/rGO), which was synthesized by the pyrolysis of a homogeneous mixture of graphene oxide (GO) and graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) in the presence of a hard SiO2 colloidal-crystal template and PBAs. As illustrated in Fig. 15(d), Co@Co-N/rGO was obtained by adding K3[Co(CN)6] to an aqueous solution (containing a silica sol, sheet-like protonated g-C3N4, GO, and Co(Ac)2), followed by calcination and HF etching to remove the SiO2. The target catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity for the ORR and HER in an alkaline electrolyte. Co@Co-N/rGO only required a potential of –180 mV (vs. RHE) to reach a current density of –10 mA cm−2 for the HER in alkaline media (Fig. 15(e)). As shown schematically in Fig. 15(f), Lin et al. [193] carried out the heterogeneous nucleation growth of NiFe-PBA nanocubes on CNTs, followed by oxygen plasma treatment with different CNT contents. Benefiting from the ordered and highly dispersed metal sites in the structure and the conductive substrate, the target catalyst only required a potential of 279 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 for the HER in alkaline media when the ratio of CNT/NiFe was optimized to 1:18. Furthermore, the current density decay of the catalyst over 100 h was negligible, revealing its robustness and reusability. Because of the different calcination temperatures, the morphologies of the electrocatalysts varied. As shown in Fig. 16(a) , the Fe nanoparticles (core-shell structures) became wrapped in N-doped graphitic nanotubes when annealed at a pyrolysis temperature of 950 °C (Fig. 16(b)) [194]. The encapsulated nanostructures, which showed the lowest onset potential (0.60 V vs. AgCl/Ag) of the catalysts prepared in the study, exhibited excellent OER performance (Fig. 16(c)). Similarly, Bu et al. [195] used a microwave annealing technique to increase the reaction temperature rapidly (within 10 s). This rapid increase prevented the aggregation of metal atoms and generated highly dispersed carbon, thereby encapsulating metal nanoparticles on the carbon cloth (Figs. 16(d) and 16(e)). The final catalyst showed excellent OER performance, reaching a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a low overpotential of 261 mV in 1.0 M KOH [195], as illustrated in Fig. 16(f). 4.1.5 HER and OER mechanisms In the overall water decomposition process, H2 and O2 generation occur at the anode and cathode, respectively [196–200]. As illustrated in Fig. 17 , the HER is a two-electron process, involving the construction of an H–H bond. In contrast, the OER is a multistep four-electron-association reaction that involves the breaking of the O–H bond and the formation of an O–O bond [201]. The thermodynamics of acidic/alkaline HER/OER reactions are summarized in Fig. 18 . In the overall water splitting reaction, HER is the cathodic reaction (Eqs. (1) and (5)). Theoretical studies have revealed that there are two different HER mechanisms involving the three possible reactions under acidic conditions (Volmer/Heyrovsky (Eqs. (2)–(3)) or Volmer/Tafel (Eqs. (2)–(4)) processes) [19,202–204]. As shown by Eqs. (6) and (7), the Volmer and Heyrovsky steps in alkaline solution are different from those under acidic conditions. Specifically, in a basic medium, it is essential to break the strong covalent O–H bond in H–O–H rather than the weak covalent O–H bond in H3O+ [205]. In addition, the thermodynamic potential (E°) of the reaction in aqueous acid (pH = 0) is 0 V, whereas that in aqueous base (pH = 14) is –0.83 V [206]. In the overall water decomposition reaction, the OER is the anodic reaction, as shown by Eqs. (9) and (14), and, like the HER, it also involves different reactions under acidic and alkaline solutions. The thermodynamic potential (E°) of the reaction in aqueous acid (pH = 0) is –1.23 V, whereas that in the aqueous base (pH = 14) is –0.40 V [206]. These potentials are relative to the hydrogen electrode, which is instructive for catalyst design. In addition, some adsorption intermediates (OH*, OOH*, and O*) are involved in both the reactions in acidic (Eqs. (10)–(13)) and basic (Eqs. (15)–(18)) media [158,168, 207,208]. 4.2 Applications of PBA-derived nanomaterials for photocatalytic hydrogen generation Solar energy, radiant light, and heat from the sun are among the most promising alternative energy sources to solve global challenges owing to their abundance, sustainability, and environmentally friendly nature [209–214]. Photocatalysts are designed to mimic the photosynthesis process in plants to produce solar fuels (hydrogen and oxygen) through water splitting [215–219]. In the early 1970s, Honda et al. [220] demonstrated an n-type TiO2 electrode that could perform photo-assisted electrochemical water oxidation, and this represents a pioneering work in the photocatalytic water splitting field. Since then, the use of semiconducting materials to achieve photocatalytic water splitting has been widely studied [221,222]. Currently, a number of semiconducting photocatalysts such as TiO2 [223–228], WO3 [229–233], CdS [234–237], g-C3N4 [238–243], BiVO4 [244–248], and metal halide perovskites [249–253] have been explored to identify highly efficient semiconducting photocatalysts and make solar fuel generation commercially viable. Although PBAs have been studied for a long time, their applications to photocatalysis have rarely been reported. Although the large cavity in PBAs can provide channels for mass transfer, as well as catalytically active centers, their insufficient light response has severely limited their use for photocatalytic utilization [254–257]. Recently, Lan et al. [254] introduced CdS as a photosensitizer to generate highly reactive Co-PBA/CdS hybrid photocatalysts. As shown in Fig. 19(a) , they produced a series of Co-PBA/CdS nanocomposites having a beaded structure via a temperature-induced self-assembly strategy. The unique beaded structures of the Co-PBA nanoparticles were anchored on the surface of CdS nanowires, as shown in Fig. 19(b). In addition, when using lactic acid as the sacrificial agent, the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution (PHE) properties of the Co-PBA/CdS nanocomposites, which are synthesized at relatively low temperatures using 82.6 wt% Co-PBA (57228 μmol h−1 g−1), are comparable to those of reported photocatalysts based on crystalline porous materials (Figs. 19(c) and 19(d)). Furthermore, according to DFT calculations, the high PHE is associated with efficient photoinduced electron–hole pair separation at the coordinated heterojunction interface between CdS and Co-PBA via the CN-Cd electron bridges. Similarly, by exploiting the intrinsic open framework of PBA [259–262], Lou et al. [258] prepared a CdS nanocage structure having a large surface area, short charge-transfer distance, and good light scattering effects, enabling highly efficient photocatalytic water reduction. As illustrated in Figs. 20(a)–(d) , CdS frame-in-cage particles were synthesized by a facile two-step sulfidation approach using Cd-PBA cubes as the precursor. As a result of the unique frame-in-cage composite architecture, the prepared CdS possesses an outstanding efficiency, having an H2 production rate of 13600 μmol h−1 g−1 when using Na2S and Na2SO3 as the hole scavengers (Fig. 20(e)). Some representative examples of PBA-derived photocatalysts used for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution are presented in Table 2 . 6 Conclusions and outlook Although PB and PBAs have been studied for a long time because of their diverse structures, studies of hollow structures and substrate-supported nanostructures for electrocatalysis began less than 10 years ago. In this review, recent trends in the synthesis of substrate-supported nanostructures and hollow PB and PBA structures, such as open hollow cages, single-shelled hollow boxes, and intricate hollow architectures (multi-shell and yolk-shell) have been introduced in detail, including synthetic methods and mechanisms of formation. In addition, considerable effort has been devoted to the study of compounds derived from PB/PBA precursors, which have great potential for electrochemical energy storage. The applications of PB/PBA-derived nanomaterials such as (hydr)oxides, phosphides, chalcogenides, and carbides for water splitting have been discussed in detail in this review, and the performance of some typical catalysts for the OER and HER are summarized in Tables 3 and 4 , respectively. From this table, we can see that Fe/Co/Ni/Mo and P/S/Se are the most common metals and nonmetals, respectively, used in the synthesis of PBA derivatives, which suggests that expanding the elemental variety of PBA templates is a potential way to develop more efficient catalysts. The applications of PB/PBAs and their derivatives to hydrogen and oxygen evolution have been well-explored, but these materials have potential for application in other areas such as carbon capture and energy conversion technology, for example, Li-S batteries [268–275] and electrocatalytic CO2 conversion [276–278]. We recommend these in-depth reviews [269] to readers interested in the application of PBAs in batteries. PB and PBAs have been widely used as electrocatalysts because of their tunable structures and elemental compositions. Although research on their synthesis is relatively mature, some aspects need further exploration and some challenges remain, especially concerning structure construction and energy conversion. In particular, we hope that the following problems will be addressed in the next few years. (1) PB/PBAs have poor electrocatalytic performance; however, they are excellent chemical precursors, and, after ex situ or in situ transformations, their derivatives exhibit excellent electrocatalytic properties. In particular, the particle size of the derivatives has a profound effect on the distribution of available active sites, and this can be adjusted by controlling the particle size of the PB/PBA precursors. (2) Currently, most studies have focused on four elements (Fe, Co, Ni, and Mn) as metal centers [111,279–285]. Expanding the elemental variety of PBA templates will increase the applications of these materials. Although metals other than Fe, Co, Ni, and Mn are not stable in PBA materials, they could ease the preparation of other PBA-derived hollow structures under mild conditions. (3) In most cases, PBAs and their derivatives are powders. Without the assistance of a polymer binder, their coating on conductive substrates is challenging, and the addition of a binder results in decreased conductivity, loss of active surface area, and insufficient structural stability [120]. In addition, during high-temperature pyrolysis, PBAs are prone to aggregation, resulting in unsatisfactory catalytic performance [121]. In comparison, there have been few reports of the in situ growth of PBAs on substrates with high mechanical strength, high electrical conductivity, and a high dispersion of active sites, and this represents a fascinating field with tremendous potential. (4) Single-shelled hollow boxes are the most common morphology of hollow PB/PBA structures reported to date. Therefore, a new challenge is the design of complex frameworks, such as core-shell, multi-shell, and open cage structures, which will provide opportunities for tailoring the physicochemical properties by regulating these intricate structures at the micro/nanoscale. (5) More effort is required to explore the reaction parameters and structure-function relationships of the target materials to understand their correlation better. More precisely, the material composition and crystal structures of PB/PBAs are highly dependent on the synthetic conditions, and have a significant impact on the material properties for energy conversion. coredata.dc:description: To meet the current energy needs of society, the highly efficient and continuous production of clean energy is required. One of the key issues facing the green hydrogen evolution is the construction of efficient, low-cost electrocatalysts. Prussian blue (PB), Prussian blue analogs (PBAs), and their derivatives have tunable metal centers and have attracted significant interest as novel photo- and electrochemical catalysts. In this review, recent research progress into PB/PBA-based hollow structures, substrate-supported nanostructures, and their derivatives for green water splitting is discussed and summarized. First, several remarkable examples of nanostructured PB/PBAs supported on substrates (copper foil, carbon cloth, and nickel foam) and hollow structures (such as single-shelled hollow boxes, open hollow cages, and intricate hollow structures (multi–shell and yolk–shell)) are discussed in detail, including their synthesis and formation mechanisms. Subsequently, the applications of PB/PBA derivatives ((hydr)oxides, phosphides, chalcogenides, and carbides) for water splitting are discussed. Finally, the limitations in this research area and the most urgent challenges are summarized. We hope that this review will stimulate more researchers to develop technologies based on these intricate PB/PBA structures and their derivatives for highly efficient, green water splitting.
